author: sky.cactus
content: Gah, I cannot figure out why the bot refuses to auto-merge any of Albertocuestacanada's PRs.

content: Is there somewhere we can see logs for it?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@194433073394352129> Where can one go to see any error logging from the merge bot?  Every PR by the afformentioned author against their EIP seems to be completely ignored by the merge bot, which makes me think it is somehow crashing while reviewing it or something.

author: sky.cactus
content: I tried hitting <https://ethlab-183014.appspot.com/merge/?repo=EIPs&pr=3209> but that errors with output that I'm not sure how to parse.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, tried <https://ethlab-183014.appspot.com/merge/?repo=ethereum%2fEIPs&pr=3209> which doesn't fail but it also doesn't return anything.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe it doesn't like the Ã± in Alberto's name (pure speculation)?

author: nickjohnson
content: The latter is the correct URL

author: nickjohnson
content: The error logs aren't available anywhere publicly I'm afraid

author: nickjohnson
content: Let me take a look

author: nickjohnson
content: > EIP 3156 is in state Review, not Draft or Last Call

author: nickjohnson
content: It's refusing to do anything because it doesn't recognise the state it's in

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, so we need to update the bot to support the Review state?

author: nickjohnson
content: Yup, I'm doing that now

author: nickjohnson
content: The new flow is Draft -> Review -> Last Call, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes.

author: nickjohnson
content: Can an EIP author make any of those transitions without editor approval?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!187490121698770945> or <@191378736254287874> (I forget who, sorry!) indicated a while back that they were going to look into contracting out to someone to move the bot to GitHub actions, which would give it a higher bus factor and visibility.  I wonder if we should bring this up again at the next EIPIP meeting <@642887713246150666>?

author: sky.cactus
content: The transition no.

author: sky.cactus
content: But they can update the EIP freely while it is in any of those states.

author: nickjohnson
content: Not even Draft to Review?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.

author: sky.cactus
content: Each state transition is when EIP editors actually look at EIPs, not during editing within a state.

author: sky.cactus
content: So the transition being blocked by editors gives us (editors) an opportunity to make sure the EIP is in good condition before moving on (they rarely are on initial PR).

author: nickjohnson
content: yup

author: nickjohnson
content: That was the theory when I was actively editing, but I didn't know if the reasoning was different for 'review'.

author: nickjohnson
content: (Personally I think that if it's not ready to review, you shouldn't merge the PR as draft - just keep it in your own fork. But never mind.)

author: nickjohnson
content: I've made the change and pushed it to the git repo, deploying it now.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thanks!

author: nickjohnson
content: No worries

author: sky.cactus

author: nickjohnson
content: Who's the malevolent dictator?

author: sky.cactus
content: Me.

author: nickjohnson
content: ðŸ˜†

author: sky.cactus
content: I keep lobbying to take away that person's seized power, but everyone just kinda shrugs.

author: nickjohnson
content: That sounds familiar.

author: sky.cactus
content: ðŸ¤”  Maybe the trick is I just need to leave a power vacuum for a year and some poor sap will show up and start doing the job.  Then once they are active I can return and there will be two of us.

content: Okay, done!

author: nickjohnson
content: I am sorry about that.

author: nickjohnson
content: Technically there are *two* active EIP editors. I just upgraded one.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@543900561460822016> has been helping some recently, but since everyone works for free it is "as time permits".  I'm hoping they can compete with me for hours wasted arguing with people over what a technical document should consist of.  ðŸ˜¬

author: nickjohnson
content: That is a bit of a turn off to participating. I'm glad there seems to be a more solid consensus on the separation between standardisation and implementation and deployment these days, at least.

author: sky.cactus
content: "Solid consensus" is easy when I only have to agree with myself.  ðŸ˜›

author: nickjohnson
content: ha!

author: nickjohnson
content: You must have had more feedback than that on the EIP 1 change?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, that one did involve more parties.

author: sky.cactus
content: But for deciding what gets merged and what doesn't, I just won't merge things that I don't think are acceptable, and since no one else merges anything it gives me effectively 100% say in what is merged.

author: nickjohnson
content: *nods*

author: sky.cactus
content: (this is the piece that I think would be valuable to break by getting more active editors)

author: nickjohnson
content: The idea behind Last Call was to make the author justify their responses to all the objections raised, making it a little less arbitrary, but it's still ultimately a judgement call.

author: sky.cactus
content: Most things that make it to Last Call these days are in pretty good shape, especially with the introduction of Review.
